case_name: Appellant v. Deputy Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, New Delhi

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 41 of 1967 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 41 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated November 21, 1966 of Delhi High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 273-D of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 21, 1966 of the Delhi High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 273-D of 1965.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Vaidialingam, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Vaidialingam, J.

facts.text: Complaint filed by Deputy Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, New Delhi (respondent) on December 31, 1962 before First Class Magistrate, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed a companyplaint, on December, 31, 1962, be- fore the First Class Magistrate. Delhi.

facts.text: Complaint alleges offences under s.120B r/w s.420 IPC and s.5 of Imports & Exports Control Act, 1947 by appellants and four others.

anchor.surface_text: alleging that the appellants, before us, and four others, had companymitted offences punishable under s. 120B, read with s. 420, I.P.C., and s. 5 of the Act.

facts.text: Complaint sets out violations of conditions of import licences granted to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplaint, fairly elaborately, sets out the various matters companytaining allegations of violations of the companyditions of the import licences granted to the appellants.

facts.text: Chief Commissioner, Delhi gave consent dated December 12, 1962 under s.196A(2) CrPC for prosecution of appellant and four others due to s.120B IPC.

anchor.surface_text: that the Chief Commissioner, Delhi, by his order, dated December 12, 1962, had given his companysent to the initiation of proceedings...

facts.text: Complainant examined as PW.3.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant was examined as P.W. 3.

facts.text: Complainant filed complaint after satisfying himself about prima facie commission of offences.

anchor.surface_text: He has stated, in his chief-examination, that he filed the companyplaint, in question, after satisfying himself about the prima facie companymission of the offences,

facts.text: Complainant received report from Special Police Establishment at end of September 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In cross-examination he has referred to the fact that he came to know about the case when he received a report from the Special Police Establishment, at the end of September 1962.

facts.text: Objection raised by Public Prosecutor that SPE report is opinion of police officer and not admissible; upheld by Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: When a question was put, as to whether he companyplainant would produce the said report, objection was raised, by the Public Prosecutor, that the said report was only the opinion of a police officer, and was number admissible, in law. This objection has been upheld by the Magistrate.

facts.text: Complainant first visited Special Police Establishment Office in September or October 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant has further stated that he visited the Special Police Establishment Office, for the first time, in companynection with the case, only in September or October 1963,

facts.text: Complaint filed on December 31, 1962 but complainant had not seen documents in police report between receiving report and filing.

anchor.surface_text: whereas the companyplaint had been filed, on December 31, 1962. He has also stated that he has number seen any of the documents, referred to in the police report, between the date when he received the report, and the date when the company- plaint was filed.

facts.text: Complainant signed complaint on December 29, 1962 after Chief Commissioner's permission obtained.

anchor.surface_text: and that the Chief Commissioners permission, to initiate proceedings, had already been obtained, when he signed the companyplaint, on December 29, 1962.

facts.text: Complainant asked Special Police Establishment to draft the complaint.

anchor.surface_text: But, he has also stated that he had asked the Special Police Establishment, to draft the company- plaint.

facts.text: Appellant filed application on September 26, 1964 before Trial Magistrate seeking no cognizance on basis of complaint.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant tiled an application, on September 26, 1964, before the Trial Magistrate, stating that, in view of the above answers given, by the companyplainant, numbercognizance should be taken,

facts.text: Trial Magistrate rejected appellant's application.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate rejected this application,

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge, Delhi confirmed Magistrate's order in revision.

anchor.surface_text: and his order was also companyfirmed, in revision, by the Additional Sessions , Judge, Delhi.

facts.text: Delhi High Court confirmed orders of subordinate courts in order under appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by these orders of the Subordinate Courts, the appellant moved the Delhi High Court, for redress. The learned Judge, of the Delhi High Court, in his order, under appeal, has companyfirmed the orders of the Subordinate Courts.

facts.text: Delhi High Court held that complaint filed by respondent on December 31, 1962 satisfies requirements of s.6 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the view of the High Court, that the companyplaint, filed by the respondent, on December 31, 1962, satisfies the requirements of s. 6 of the Act, is perfectly companyrect.

facts.text: Respondent is officer authorized by Central Government to file complaints under s.5 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In this case, companynsel points out, there is numbercontroversy that the respondent is an officer, authorized by the Central Government, to file companyplaints, under s. 5 of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds s.6 of Act only requires written complaint by authorized officer; no need for prior consideration of all facts like in sanction cases.

anchor.surface_text: We are number inclined to accept the companytentions of Mr. Sen, that the principles laid down in these decisions, which relate to the question of sanction. have any application to the filing of companyplaints, under s. 6 of the Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Punishable offence requiring complaint under s.6 for cognizance

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 of the Act, relating to cognizance of offences, is as follows No Court shall take cognizance of any offence punishable under section 5 except upon complaint in writing made by an officer authorized in this behalf by the Central Government by general or special order, and noCourt inferior to that of a Presidency Magistrate or a Magistrate of the first class shall try any such offence

concepts.interpretation: Only requires written complaint by authorized officer; no need for detailed prior consideration of facts like in sanction cases; removes bar to cognizance once requirements met

issues.text: the validity of the complaint filed by the Deputy Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, New Delhi, the respondent herein, under s. 5 read with s. 6 of the Imports Exports Control Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: The sole point, which arises for companysidera- tion, in this appeal, by special leave, directed against the order of the High Court of Delhi, dated November 21, 1966, is about the validity of the companyplaint filed by the Deputy Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, New Delhi, the respondent herein, under s. 5 read with s. 6 of the Imports Exports  Control  Act, 1947  Act XVIII of 1947   hereinafter referred to as the Act .

issues.text: whether s. 6 of the Act is mandatory and requires that the facts constituting the offence were placed before the complainant and that, after a proper consideration of those facts, the complaint has been instituted

anchor.surface_text: According to the learned companynsel, s. 6 of the Act is mandatory and, before a Court can take companynizance of an offence punishable under s. 5, the prosecution will have to establish that the facts companystituting the offence, were placed before the companyplainant and that, after a proper companysideration of those facts, the companyplaint has been instituted-in this case, by P.W.3.

issues.text: whether the principles laid down in sanction cases have any application to the filing of complaints under s. 6 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: We are number inclined to accept the companytentions of Mr. Sen, that the principles laid down in these decisions, which relate to the question of sanction. have any application to the filing of companyplaints, under s. 6 of the Act.

issues.text: whether an adverse inference is to be drawn against the prosecution for not producing the Special Police Establishment report

anchor.surface_text: But Mr. Sen relied upon the decision of this Court in Feroz Dins Case 1  in support of his argument that cases in which sanction is necessary, to enable a Court to take companynizance of offences, and cases, in which a mere companyplaint, is to be filed by a public officer, without the requirement of any sanction, have been treated on a par,

arguments.claim: Section 6 of the Act is mandatory and requires that the facts constituting the offence were placed before the complainant and that, after proper consideration of those facts, the complaint was instituted

anchor.surface_text: According to the learned counsel, s. 6 of the Act is mandatory and, before a Court can take cognizance of an offence punishable under s. 5, the prosecution will have to establish that the facts constituting the offence, were placed before the complainant and that, after a proper consideration of those facts, the complaint has been instituted-in this case, by P.W.3.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: erved with companyplete strictness, as the object of the provision for sanction is that the authority, giving the sanction, should be able to companys

arguments.court_reasoning: Principles laid down in sanction cases do not apply to filing of complaints under s.6 of the Act

arguments.claim: Prosecution must produce Special Police Establishment report to show facts were placed before complainant; non-production leads to adverse inference against prosecution

anchor.surface_text: Counsel also pointed out that the prosecution could have, very well, placed. before the Court the report of the Special Police Establishment to show that the necessary facts, which formed the basis of the complaint, were placed before the complainant but, in this case, the prosecution had declined to produce the report, as will be seen from the objections raised by it. Therefore, under those circumstances, an inference will have to be drawn against the prosecution, and the normal presumption should be that the evidence which could be, but had not been, produced would, if produced be unfavourable to the person who withholds it

arguments.claim: There is no distinction in principle between provisions requiring previous sanction and those requiring a complaint by a particular officer

anchor.surface_text: In fact, we understood Mr. Sen to contend that there is no distinction, in principle, between provisions in statutes providing for the taking of cognizance of offences,, only on the previous sanction of any particular authority, and provisions providing, simpliciter, for a complaint being filed, by a particular person or officer.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: erved with companyplete strictness, as the object of the provision for sanction is that the authority, giving the sanction, should be able to companys

arguments.court_reasoning: Sanction principles require consideration of facts by authority; s.6 merely requires written complaint by authorized officer, removing bar to cognizance

anchor.surface_text: Counsel also pointed out that, in this case, the High Court has proceeded on the basis that the filing of a complaint, by P.W. 3, is merely a mechanical act, which view is not justified, in law.

arguments.court_reasoning: Filing is not mechanical but s.6 only requires written complaint by authorized officer satisfying plain words

Khanna, learned counsel for the respondent-com- plainant, has pointed out that the principles, enunciated by the appellants counsel, do not apply to cases where the statute, as in this case, simpliciter provides for a complaint being made, by the particular officer, mentioned therein. In such cases, counsel points out, the Court has only to see whether the person or authority, mentioned therein, has initiated the proceedings, by filing a complaint, in the manner, referred to in the particular provision.

arguments.claim: CrPC provisions distinguish between cognizance on complaint by specified person vs. on sanction

anchor.surface_text: in this connection, counsel referred us to the provisions, contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure, some of which provide for cognizance being taken, of offences, only on a complaint made by a person or officer, mentioned therein, and in other cases, where taking cognizance of offences is prohibited, except on a sanction given by an authority, e.g., ss. 195, 197, 198, etc.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: erved with companyplete strictness, as the object of the provision for sanction is that the authority, giving the sanction, should be able to companys

arguments.court_reasoning: Sanction cases like Gokulchand require proof of fact consideration; not applicable to s.6

arguments.claim: Principles from sanction cases (Gokulchand etc.) require sanctioning authority to consider facts constituting offence

anchor.surface_text: The principle, that the burden of proving that a requisite sanction has been obtained, rests on the prosecution, and that such burden involves proof that the sanctioning authority had given the sanction in reference to the facts on which the proposed prosecution was to be based, facts which might appear on the fact of the sanction, or might be proved by extraneous evidence. is now well-settled, by the decision of the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council, in Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King 1 .

arguments.claim: Sanction principles from Judicial Committee and SC cases (Madan Mohan, Jaswant Singh, Feroz Din) do not apply to s.6 complaints

anchor.surface_text: We are not inclined to accept the contentions of Mr. Sen, that the principles laid down in these decisions, which relate to the question of sanction. have any application to the filing of complaints, under s. 6 of the Act.

arguments.claim: S.6 only requires written complaint by authorized officer; once satisfied, bar to cognizance removed

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 only insists that the complaint is to be in writing and that it must be made by an officer, authorised in that behalf. The complaint, in this case, has been made by the respondent in writing, and that he is an authorised officer, in this behalf, has not been challenged. The limitation, contained in s. 6, is only regarding the particular officer who could file a complaint and, when once he satisfies those requirements, the bar is removed to the taking of cognizance by a Court, on a complaint, made in accordance with s. 6.

arguments.claim: Literal construction: give effect to natural meaning of clear statutory words

anchor.surface_text: In construing the provisions of a statute it is essential for a court, in the first instance, to give effect to the natural meaning of the words used therein, if those words are clear enough.

arguments.claim: Complaint filed by respondent conforms to plain words of s.6

anchor.surface_text: Going by the plain words, contained in s. 6 of the Act, we are satisfied that the complaint, in this case, filed by the respondent, can be considered to be in conformity with the provisions, contained therein.

arguments.claim: Feroz Din case observations on sanction validity confined to its facts (complaint under authority with sanction); not applicable to s.6

anchor.surface_text: This Court, in that case nevertheless, apply, if the Government itself had filed the complaint, as it was entitled to, under s. 34 1 . Therefore, the observations made, in that case, regarding the validity of sanction , will have to be confined to the facts of that case. No such question arise, with regard to the matter before us.

arguments.claim: Complaint satisfies requirements of s.6; High Court view correct

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the view of the High Court, that the complaint, filed by the respondent, on December 31, 1962, satisfies the requirements of s. 6 of the Act, is perfectly correct.

holdings.text: We are not inclined to accept the contentions of Mr. Sen, that the principles laid down in these decisions, which relate to the question of sanction have any application to the filing of complaints, under s. 6 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are number inclined to accept the companytentions of Mr. Sen, that the principles laid down in these decisions, which relate to the question of sanction. have any application to the filing of companyplaints, under s. 6 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sanction cases require authority to consider facts constituting offence before granting sanction as condition precedent; s.6 merely requires written complaint by authorized officer to remove bar to cognizance.

holdings.text: Section 6 only insists that the complaint is to be in writing and that it must be made by an officer, authorised in that behalf. The complaint, in this case, has been made by the respondent in writing, and that he is an authorised officer, in this behalf, has not been challenged. The limitation, contained in s. 6, is only regarding the particular officer who could file a complaint and, when once he satisfies those requirements, the bar is removed to the taking of cognizance by a Court, on a complaint, made in accordance with s. 6.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 only insists that the companyplaint is to be in writing and that it must be made by an officer, authorised in that behalf. holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of s.6 specifies only writing and authorization requirements; fulfillment removes statutory bar to cognizance unlike sanction which demands prior fact consideration.

holdings.text: In construing the provisions of a statute it is essential for a court, in the first instance, to give effect to the natural meaning of the words used therein, if those words are clear enough.

The companyplaint, in this case, has been made by the respondent in writing, and that he is an authorised officer, in this behalf, has number been challenged.
The result is, the view of the High Court, that the companyplaint, filed by the respondent, on December 31, 1962, satisfies the requirements of s. 6 of the Act, is perfectly companyrect.
